div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Icilma.

div.head: THE THEORY OF LIFE ON MARS.
div.p: On Saturday, July 6, the planet Mars and the Earth were in "opposition," and astronomers were basy with telescopes and cameras observing and obtaining photographic impressions of our nearest neighbour in the celestial ether.

"Project yourself into the future, if you can, and imagine this Earth as it will be some millions of years hence. At that remote period its mountains will have been levelled, its fertile areas will have shrivelled to arid deserts; its gases will partly have floated away, and its atmosphere will consequently have been impoverished and attenuated; its weather will have become so wearisomely unvaried, its skies so monotonously serene that the passage of a cloud will be chronicled by historians; its seas and its lakes will have dried up utterly; its oceans will have poured through cracks and caverns into its interior ; and all the water that now covers four-fifths of its surface will have dwindled to a small plain of ice and snow deposited about each Pole. That image of the Earth's future plight may be considered a fairly accurate picture of the present condition of Mars, as it has been anfolded by the. more recent discoveries," says Mr. Waldemar Kaempffert, in the July "Windsor."

Prof. Lester Ward contributes an article on Mars to the "Brown Alumni Monthly", of which the "Westminster Gazette" gives a long abstract. The Professor "assumes that Mars has passed through much the same stages as the Barth has done, and, applying the geological principle of uniformitarianism, he finds an exact parallel between the two planets up to the end of their respective Tertiary periods. He then states that we have now the best reasons for supposing that the Psychozoic age, upon which we are but just entering, so to speak, began on Mars at the opening of the Quaternary period."

"The visible aspect of Mars has been altered in such a way as to show that the social efficiency of the Martian race is at a far higher level than we have yet attained. We see a race of vast antiquity and supreme wisdom clinging desperately to the place of its birth, balf gasping for breath, hoarding up every drop of its precious water, but doomed in the comparatively near future to face the lingering death of a dying world. In like manner, we too must anticipate the soene which Prof. Ward deftly expresses by changing two letters in the famous line from Horace : 'voir le dernier (hu)main à son dernier soupir.' A gloomy picture I to which he claims there is another side of the quarter of a million years of man's life on earth he has been conscious of his existence about 10,000 years, and only within 2000 years has accomplished anything of value, to himself ; while his great work may be said to have been accomplished within the last two centuries. The Psychozoic age, therefore, still lies before him."

" What science has definitely ascertained up to now about Mars," said Sir William Huggins to a "Daily News" representative, "is that there is ice formed at the poles of the planet, and that this mass of congealed matter melts when the Martian summer occurs. It has been further ascertained that there are markings on the planet itself, in the shape of lines more or less straight. The existence of some of these marking, has been since confirmed by photographs taken by Mr. Per. cival Lowell, of the Lowell Observatory, in Arizona. But to jump to the conclusion, as Mr. Lowell does, that the markings are canals out or dog by the inhabitants of Mars cannot be regarded as absolutely certain. That Mars is inhabited may not be an impossibility, in the light of our present knowledge of the conditions of life."

div.p: One of Cook's cargo boats collided on Saturday last with a sailing vessel loaded with beans, which immediately sank. The crew, consisting of Rais Mahomed Abou Saber and his three brothers, were rescued. The Plague.

div.head: Burglary at Khartoum.
div.p: A burglar made an unsuccessful attempt last Friday week to break into the house of Mr. Papini, the proprietor of the Gordon Hotel, Khartoum. But Mr. Papini discovered him on the premises and scared him off with one or two pistol shots. Word was sent to the police, who at once started investigations that are expected to lead to the discovery and arrest of the culprit. A remarkable fact, however, about the affair was that no ghaffir appeared on the scene, in spite of the commotion which necessarily ensued. A Curse of the Sudan.

One of the tropical inaladies which prevail in the Sudan is blackwater fever. The Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine has determined to send an expedition to this continent to investigate the causes and possible remedies of this fatal fever. The expedition consists of Dr. Barrett, of Birmingham ; Dr. Yorke, of Liverpool University ; Dr. Prout, who has had medical experience on the West Coast Colonel Bruce, R.A.M.C, the discoverer of the canse and cure of Malta fever ; Professor Carter, and Sir Robert Boyce, F.R.S. A Theban Temple.

A provisional plan describing the temple of King Neb-hapet-Ra Mentuhetep of the XIth Dynasty, which lies to the south of the Kreat temple built by Queen Hatshepsu withir the cliff circle of Deir el-Bahari, has been pre pared by Messrs. C.R. Peers, Ayrton, and Currelly, and, with the description by Messrs Naville, Hall, and Ayrton, appears in the first volume now ready. The final plans, by Mr Somers Clarke and M. Fabio, will appear ir the second volume. The excavations bave row been completed, and the whole building is cleared. The date assigned to the temple is about 2700 B.C. The site was indicated some 16 centuries later by a Royal Commission o the XXth Dynasty, which reported that "the pyramid-tomb of King Neb-hapet-Ra, deceased which is in Tjesret" (Deir el-Bahari) was in good order. The interests of archeology were it seems, in those days not neglected by the Government.

div.head: Sun Blinds.
div.p: We would draw the attention of the Muni cipality to the danger and discontort to which pedestrians are subjected by the sun blinds over many of the shops in the less importan streets of the city. These blinds are, in many instances, considerably less than six feet above the pavement level, with the resul that people walking on the pavement are ap to be unpleasantly reminded of their existenc by their heads. coming into violent contac with a steel rod. Granted that it is advisable to take heed where one is going, due obsery ance in that respect does not alter the fac that pavements are made for the convenience of foot passengers whose rights should not b encroached upon by individual shopkeepers o frequent have been the complaints in th press of shop and café proprietors being allowed to place their goods or chairs and tables across the pavement, to the detrimen of passers by, that we feel it is almost useles to again refer to the matter.

div.head:
THE MEDITERRANEAN FLEET.
ENTERTAINMENT AT BEYROUT.
div.p: (FROM OUR Owy CORRESPONDENT.)

Beyrout, July 19. The British Fleet visited our port in strag. ling detachments and disappointed us in the nope of witnessing the imposing spectacle of a all array. Early on Friday morning the lagship "Queen" and the sister first class attleship "Irresistible" arrived and exchanged alute guns with the barracks. The British Consul General paid an official call on Admiral Bir Charles Drory, and was followed by Rear Admiral Faiek Pasha of the Mediterranean Flying Squadron. In the afternoon Khalil Pasha, the Vali, Kemal Bey, the Director of Police, Abdel Kader Effendi El Dana, President of the Municipality, and Ismet Pasha, Milicary Commandant, accompanied with Khairy Bey, Head Physician of the Military Hospital,
aid official visits to the flagship, guns being fired in the prescribed number for each visitor according to his rank.

In the evening an entertainment was given by the members of the Sporting Club and their President the British Consul General, at the Club itself. Owing to many members of the Club being in mourning, the attendance of ladies was very poor, and the hot weather was also a great drawback.

On Saturday the "Barham" arrived and anchored inside the harbour. On the saine day a garden party wasgiven in the well-known garden of Rustein Pasha overlooking the Beyrout river. On the 14th instant a paper chase was organzed, and, despite the heat, this exciting sport was greatly enjoyed by our visitors From the sea, whose life is circumscribed by steel barriers and the dimensions of a warship.
On the 15th an "At Home" was held by the Admiral, and invitations were sent to the members of the British Colony and some of the notabilities of the town. The after deck

designed for the reception was tastefully decorated with flags and flowers. The mess room was converted into a buffet, and one of the casemates into a bar and smoking room for gentlemen. In the evening the Vali, at a suggestion, it is said, froin high quarters at Constantinople, gave a dinner at Seraglio to the Admiral and this staff. The Consular Corps and other notables were also invited.

On the 17th the Admiral returned the compliment by a banquet on board the flagship, to which were also invited some of the chief civil and military authorities. The after-deck was beautifully illuminated and outlined by a row of multicolored electric globes. The band header its programme with the Turkish National hymn, thus reciprocating the courtesy of the British National Anthem having been the first welcoming air played by the Turkish hand during the dinner at the Seraglio.

Early yesterday morning the flagship and the "Irresistible" sailed, and immediately after the "Venerable" and the "Prince of Wales" arrived from Jafia. The customary exchange of salutes was made. In the afternoon of the same day the second cruiser "Diana" arrived from Port Said and delivered the mail under quarantine.

div.head: THE NILE
div.p: A correspondent writes :
After reading your review of Captain Lyon's works the following thought, occurred to me and may, to the student of cause and effect, provide an interesting article.
1. The Nile, depending on rainfall, rainfall on evaporation, we come to the question-what effect had the clearing of the sudd on the Nile flood ?

2. The sadd itself, being gradual growth, gradually retarded the floods, as gradually increased the area of evaporation i.e. the swamps in the Soudan, until the increased weight of water itself forced a passage through and made by its action a clear river once more. From the above might be deduced the theory that the one and sole cause of Egypt's seven years lean and seven years of plenty was explained in one word--sudd.

i distinctly remember the flood following the year in which the Soudan officials cleared the sudd : it rose rapidly, earlier than usual, but was as quickly over and following it was a very poor summer supply. The early volume of the flood caused great uneasiness and anticipation of disaster to the banks etc. The following year, according to the seven years theory, we should have had an increased volume, but this did not happen and there has only been one year of fairly average flood, since, that of 1906. So that by artificially clearing the obstruction it may be that all previous data bas been made useless. In studying ont the question there is of course another question, does the water evaporated in the swamps fall locally or has it a wider influence, the direction and force of the monsoons will doubtless provide this information, but it must influence the local rainfall to a certain extent.

The subject is interesting and would be worth following by examination of statistics of the different years that have been compiled, also a comparison of good years or the reverse in Egypt, with the same periods in India.

div.head:
THE VIVANTE MYSTERY.
THE AFFAIR
RECAPITULATED.
div.p: THEORIES TO BE CONSIDERED.

So great has been the interest aroused by the mystery of the death of Vivante, that peculation as to the mode in which the Leceased met his death is made on all sides, nd new theories are offered daily by woulde amateur detectives. We, however, as our eaders are well aware, have been at great pains o obtain the follest and latest details daily, nd in consequence of the many suggestions which are being offered by those who have nerely followed the details from day to day we onsider that it will be useful to recapitulate he event in its entirety. All information which me publish is from those who met the deceased on the night on which the crime was comnitted, for we naturally agree with the authorities in the rejection of the theory of suicide.
The Night OF THE CREME.- According to Mr. Conegliano, on the evening of the crime, Vivante took supper with Mr. Conegliano. At
quarter to ten he bade good night to mis host, and went to the café Mohamed Aly,
ituated in the Place des Consuls (Rue de la Poste).
According to Mr. Nacamuli, Vivante was net by him at the café at 11.15 p.m. and conmersed with him until half past one in the morning, at which hour they went together to

he hotel, where both of them were staying. Mr. Nacamuli remained with Vivante in the atter's bedroom until a quarter to two, at which moment he returned to his rooms, and ne declares that throughout the night he did not hear any noise. At five minutes to eight Mr. Nacamuli was hurriedly called to see the body of Vivante.

The following are the depositions of the commercial traveller in jewellery who occupied che next room to Vivante :- About a quarter co three in the morning he heard a noise in Vivante's room, a muffled vocal sound, and a neavy thud on the floor. The noise lasted abont Cour minutes, and he then heard someone open and shut the door and go along the corridor, and then his attention was attracted by the closing of another door. From that moment until the hotel was astir he heard no Further noise.

At five minutes to eight (following the infor. mation afforded us by the proprietor) Vivante's servant went to take the morning's mail to his naster. Knocking at the door, he received no Answer and therefore entered the room unang vered. Seeing Vivante lying at the foot of his ped his head hanging down over his chest, with a mope which was unknotted, round his neck, the servant called the man in attendance, who afterwards called the proprietor of the hotel. The latter removed the rope, and struck the victim of the crime across the face with a wet towel. .

The deceased was wearing his under-vest and stockings and his feet were entangled in the inosquito net, which had been torn. The bedclothes had not been drawn down and verything in the room was in order. The shutters were closed but the window was open. Vivante, it will be remembered, never locked the door of his room. The proprietor suspects no one but the young and fair man who had engaged a room the same evening and had presented a visiting card which did not belong to him and bore the name of Mr. de Bellegarde.

THE SCENE OF THE CRIME.--The hotel in which the crime took place has a court in the centre and the rooms are placed in a double row on each floor. The room which Vivante occupied was on the second storey near the staircase and with a window looking upon the street. Next to and communicating with Vivante's room was that occupied on the night by the travelling jeweller, Mr. Koch. This room was at an angle of the building. On the same floor and almost at the diagonally opposite angle was the room which was occupied by Nacamuli, and that which was engaged by the young man upon whom strong suspicion of implication in the affair has fallen, is abont half way between those of Nacamuli and Vivante respectively.

MOST PROBABLE THEORY.-According to these facts, the most probable theory of the committal of the crime is that Vivante was surprised by his assassin, as he had neither time to shout or make an effort to defend himself. If the murderer were hidden under the bed he could not have reached Vivante without attracting his attention, and on the other hand be could not have entered by the door without Vivante hearing the opening and closing of it, and the man's footsteps. How is it, too, if such were the case that the commercial traveller heard someone leave the room immediately after the crime, but heard no one enter it before?

We can only suppose two things :-(1) that the assassin was known to Vivante, who did not fear any attack from him, (2) that he was hidden under the bed and waited until Vivante was asleep. This latter theory, however, is discountenanced by the fact that the bed was not disturbed, as it must inevitably have been had Vivante been strangled while sleeping and dragged on to the floor.

The remaining theory, therefore, is that Vivante met his death at the hands of an acquaintance of sufficient intimacy that he would undress before him. In such a case the assassin must have cleverly concealed the rope and at a moment when Vivante's back was turned quiokly twisted it round his neck and by a sharp turn smartly garrotted his victim with a coup du Père François,

A similar theory is also accepted by the police, with the exception that two persons were concerned. By this theory Vivante was engaged in conversation with an acquaintance and was taken by surprise from behind, the accomplice whipping the rope round his neck, and the rope then being drawn tight by both men.

div.head: THE SUDAN
div.p: THE BELGIAN EVACUATION.
op of commandanesen, as or
In a note on the relation between the Belgians in the Congo and south-western Sudan territory the "Sudan Times" writes :

"The evacuation by the Belgian authorities of the stations they had occupied within Sudan territory is reported by our Egyptian contemporary, "Al-Akhbar." This marks the last stage in the settlement of the difficulty that had ensued between the two Governments about this matter.

"The trouble began, as may be remembered, when Commandant Lumière with a force made up of native troops and Belgian officers, made an expedition into Sudan territory, which was claimed for purely scientific purposes.

"It was discovered however by an officer who had been sent by the Sudan Government on a 1 punitive, expedition against the rebellous Chief Yamibo, that the Belgian expedition was more military than scientific, and that they had occupied several points beyond the borders of the Congo State or the Lado Enclave. The Sudan Government protested against this occupation and requested the Belgian forces to withdraw. This they refused to do, claiming that the stations they occupied were located in their own territory.

"Thereupon the Sudan Government issued orders forbidding the transport of any provisions or other goods by Bahr el Gebel steamers to the Lado. The controversy about the disputed territory was then transferred to London and Brussels"; and was ultimately settled by the Belgian Government agreeing to withdraw its troops from the disputed stations and reiterating its agreement to withdraw from the Lado upon the death of King Leopold.

"On its part, the Sudan Government consented to allow the construction by the Congo Free State of a railway connecting the Congo with the Nile, which would serve as an outlet for the Congo State and in the same time be very beneficial to the Sudan.

The Sudan Government has recently sent & commission consisting of Bimbashi Newcombe, of the Sudan Government Railways, and three officers of the Egyptian Army. They were to meet with three Belgian delegates and together make the preliminary surveys necessary for the projected Nile-Congo Railway.

"We have as yet received no information from the Government about the work accomplished by this commission, which by the way has not yet returned from its mission, as incorrectly stated in some Egyptian papers. But we are in hope that the Government will supply us with full information about the work of this committee, as well as abont the points evacuated by the Belgian troops, and the particulars of the evacuation.

"The recent step taken by the Belgian Government, i.e. their decision to annex the Congo Free State, is going to bring that region very prominently into public notice : and information about it will be received by the public with particular interest."

div.head: SHEIKH ABOU NADDARA.
div.p: A Paris correspondent, writing on the 14th inst., says :

"Yesterday I paid a visit to the offices of the old Egyptian newspaper at 48 Rue Richer, which has been run by Sheikh Abou Naddara. The old Sheikh was very pleased to see me and told me many tales about his Arabic-French organ, which used to defend Egyptian interests | against Ismail. The Sheikh still writes in the interests of the people of Egypt. He is not a follower of Mustapha Pasha Kamel and does not approve of his methods. The Sheikh considers that the first duty of an Egyptian journalist is to use his pen in favour of the development and progress of the Egyptians in science and art, for by this means they can gain their liberty and not by Kamel's methods."

div.head: SPANISH IN EGYPT.
div.p: Spanish is one among the many languages spoken in Egypt, and its adherents in the Nile valley are said to amount to no less than 20,000 persons. It is needless to say that this is not due to the Spanish colony in Egypt which is very small. The language is used among many Jews here, who are the descendants of those expelled from Spain on August 1st, 1492, by Ferdinand the Catholic, and Isabella of Spain. The Jews who came thence to Egypt were few in number and they soon - lost the use of Castilian for Arabic. Those of their race here, who speak the former tongue, are newcomers from other parts of the Levant. There is a Spanish newspaper in Cairo, "Vara," edited and owned by Mr. Abraham Galante. That gentleman in March gave a lecture on the Spanish language in the Orient, before the Egyptian Institute, and we are glad to find that the lecture has been published in pamphlet form. This little essay is full of interesting facts about a curious philological freak which still continues to flourish after four hundred years. There are quite a number of Spanish newspapers in the Levant at the present time, supported by Spanish speaking Jews. These are "El Tiempo" and "El Telegrafo," of Constantinople, "La Epoca" and "El Avenir," of Salonica, "La Buena Esperanza," "El Novelista," "El Messerret," and "El Comercial," of Smyrna, "El Achofar," of Philippoli, "El Dia," "La Luz," and "La Tolerancia," of Sofia, and "La Vara" of Cairo. We cordially recommend this pamphlet to all interested in the by ways of the Babel of the Eastern Mediterranean.

"LA Langue Espagnolo en Orient et ses déformation. Conférence faite le 4 mars 1907 a l'Institut Egyptien (Prix: 1 Franc.) Le Caire, Imp. Kermons & Zara, 1907. Abraham Galante Dirocteur du Journal LA Van

FOURTH RACE, 5.30 p.m. SELLING Race of P.T. 2,000. Por Arabs that have not won a selling race since 1st January 1906. Winner to be sold for P.T. 5,000. 7 lbs allowed for every P.T. 1,000 less than that price. Top weight 11.0. Distance 5 furlongs. Entrance P.T. 125.

FIFTH RACE, 6 p.m. BULKELEY PLATE of P.T. 2,500, viz: P.T. 2,000 to the winner and P.T. 500, to 2nd horse. Por Arab ponies that have not won a race since 1st April 1906. Weight for age and inches with penalties. Distance round the course. Entrance P.T. 125.

SIXTH RACE, 6.30 p.m.* SIDI GABER PLATs of P.T. 2,800, viz: P.T. 2,000 to the winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. Por Arabs that have not won a race since the 1st April 1906. Weight for age with penalties. Distance round the course. Entrance PT. 125.
Entries will close at 6 p.m. on Saturday, 17th proxo.

Entries will be published in the "Bgyptian Gazette" on Tuesday, 20th proxo. Measuring day will be Saturday 17th August 1907 at 4 p.m. at the Sporting Club Grounds. Starting declarations must be made in writing before 6 p.m. on Friday the 23rd August 1907 at the office of the Secretary and must contain the weight to be carried and the name of the jockey. Forms of starting declarations can be obtained from the Secretary. The order of running will be the same as that in which the races are on this programme. Ten entries the each race must be received, the property of 532 bona-fide different owners, otherwise the stakes will be reduced to P.T. 1,250 of which P.T.250 to go to 2nd horse, the entrance fee being reduced to P.T. 75.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Khedive has conferred the 3rd class order of the Osmanieh upon Miralai W. H. Persse Bay, O.C. cavalry, on the occasion of the expiration of his term of service with the Egyptian Army. Persse Bey is replaced in his command of the cavalry by Kaimakam C.H. Leveson Bey, transferred from the Sadan Government.

The following Army order has been issued: The Sirdar desires to express his regret at the retirement from the Egyptian Army of El Miralai Persse Bey, and to place on record his appreciation of the good services rendered by this officer for the ten years that he has been employed with His Highness The Khedivo's Troops. During this period, El Miralai Persse Bey served contineously with the Cavalry. which arın he commanded for the last seven and a half years. He took part in the following Campaigns and Actions in the Sudan :Dongola, 1896.--Hafir and Firket. Nile, 1897. Nile, 1898.-Atbara (wounded) and Khartoum. Sudan, 1904.-Jerok. The Sirdar desires on behalf of all ranks of the Egyptian Army to wish El Miralai Persse Bey every success in his future career.

Major-General the Hon. Sir Reginald A.. Talbot, K.C.B., who was Chief of the Army of Occupation in Egypt from 1899 to 1902, Bucceeds the late Major General G. Salis-Schwabe, C.B., as Colonel of the 8rd. (Prince of Wales') Dragoon Guards. Sir Reginald has had a very distinguished career. He took part in the opera tions against Cetewayo, and in the Egyptian campaign of 1882. In the attempt to relieve General Gordon, Sir Reginald commanded the heavy camel regiment, and for his servioes he received the Companionship of the Bath. Prior to his appointment to the Egyptian command, he was for six years Military Attache at Paris, and commanded the Cavalry Brigade at Alder shot from 1896-1899. He is in his sixty-seventh year.
Bimbashi R.S. Wilson and Bimbashi R.P.8. Elderton, both of the Sudan Government, have been promoted to the rank of Kaimakam.
Bimbashi Lowther, Artillery, B. A., and Bimbashi Stokes, Assistant Director of Works, Sudan Government, have been granted one month's extension of leave to the 28rd and 15th September respectively.
Mr. T. Russell, inspector to the Ministry of the Interior, has been granted three months | leave of absence from the 30th inst,

div.head: PUBLIC SECURITY IN BEHERA.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "PAYPTIAN GAZETTE.
Dear Sir,

I see in your journal of the 20th inst. a letter on the "Public Security in Behera" from one who is favourable to British administration. The "terrible accidents" to which he refers are not such, but most carefully thought and worked out plans. One of the chief factors in these crimes is the lust for vengeance for imaginary and actual wrongs ; another is of course the lust for money. I am continually hearing of most brutal murders committed in the Province, there being no fewer than eight to my knowledge since | the latter part of April, the latest being

that of a lady. When the details of these crimes are openly discussed, and the names of the perpetrators common property, I cannot imagine why the Government cannot take steps to arrest the criminals. When they are arrested, the case is sometimes distnissed because of the evidence of witnesses, which has | been tampered with. Why these bad characters, who are well known to the Government Officials, are not dispatched to some remote place I cannot make out. There are, in certain districts, gangs of these men who terrorise the whole place, demanding blackmail, and removing those who in any way interfere with their plans. Of course robbery is also one of their amusements, just to let the fellaheen know they must knuckle under. If some of your readers heard only half of what I know is the truth, they would raise an outory. Hoping that the Government has the officials, either native or English, who can bring these criminals to book.
I remain Yours trnly

div.head: THE FINANCIAL CRISIS AND NATIVE
div.p: "PUBLIC OPINION.".
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "BAYPTIAN GAZETTR." Dear Sir,
Native public opinion is rapidly forming. Here is an example of that brilliant, intelligent, splendid capacity of the Arab, with | which the writings of Mustapha Kamel have

made us familiar. | Travelling to town from Ramleh last night in the electric railway, I overheard the following conversation between foar Arabs, gravely discusing the political situation and "la Crise." Said one, "It is Lord Cromer who took away all the money with him. On leaving he told the Minister of Finance to give him eighteen million pounds. After he had gone, it was fonnd that he was only entitled to fifteen niillion. So he was requested to return the surplus of three millions, which he forthwith did, being convinced of the mistake."

A short pause for grave reflection. "If" commented one of the party "Mustafa Kamel had not sent Lord Cromer away, all that money would still have been in the country."| The obvionsness of this gradually dawned upon the other participators in the discussion. Chorus of approval : "Khawaga, weyak hak."
Yours truly,
Rex.
Cromes show
out the

1 It might be thought that such opinions as the above were only among the uneducated olasses, but the following from Mustapha Pasha Kamel's newspaper "Al Lowa," shows that the opinion that Lord Cromer deliberately brought about the crisis is industriously propagated in the vernacular press :
"It is said that our defeated enemy, having known that his false accusations brought
against Egypt have proved a failure in revengJing himself on the Egyptians, began to en

gineer some plots against them at London, trying to cripple the coming cotton market through spreading unfounded rumours, to the effect that the Egyptian peasantry are, by nature of their present financial state, obliged to sell their cotton crop at any price that might be advanced to them.
"We believe that our enemy will proye unsuccessful for the second time, but this does not prevent ns from taking the necessary steps against such plotting and thrusting in the dark."

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURS
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à 11h. 1/a.m.). Il y a eu ce matin une amélioration sens sur tonte la ligne de la cote, non pas qur échanges aient été nombreux mais les vend. ont disparo en partie et des acheteurs les remplacés On achète, ou plutôt il y a des a teurs ; cette découverte & ranimé la place corbeille a présenté ce matin une anima inoure depuis plusieurs semaines. La raison ce changement subit résiderait dans l'existe d'un découvert tant à Londres qu'ici, qu serait en train de balayer. Cette hypothèse rien d'invraisemblable ; elle est même la se probable, car au fond il n'y a absolument de changé la situation tant locale que ge rale. Tout au plus pourrait-on invoquer rapidité exagérée de la baisse, qui devait fo ment un jour ou l'autre amener une réact au moins passagère.

Les valeurs dirigeantes ayant été demand d'une façon particulière ont naturellement néficié d'une plus-value appréciable. Ce scelles aussi qui ont donné lieu au plus gre nombre de transactions, bien que ce nom ait été réduit.

C'est ainsi que l'Agricole s'avance de 7 à 7 7/8, la National Bank de 18 13/16 9/16, la Delta Light de 9 7/16 à 9 1/2, la Da de 135/16 a 13 3/8 et l'Obligation Foncier 289 l'ancienne et 251 la nouvelle à 293 et 2 respectivement

A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a gagn 4 francs, vendredi passé, à 678. La Banqu. d'Athènes a passé, samedi, de 111 à 114 france

Heureusement influencé par la meilleure tenue des valeurs égyptiennes à Londres et Paris, notre marché a montré, ce matin, un certaine fermeté, bien que les affaires aient éte assez restreintes. Ces bonnes dispositions son apparemment appelées à s'accentuer, surtou si l'on continue à ne pas se laisser impressionner par les rumeurs alarmantes de toutes sortes que le parti baissier s'emploie de plus en plus à propager dans la vue de maintenir une dé Pression qui a outrageusement dépassé les limites rationnelles.
Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National & gagné 1/4 à 18 3/4 et l'Agricole 1/8 à 7 5/8. Les parts de fondateur de la Société Générale Egyptienne ont été ramenées à 29-30.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'est relevée à 1 1/4. La part de fondateur Estates s'est tassée à £2 314-3. Les Markets ont faibli à 25 sh. 6, les New Egyptian à 13 gb., tjes Hooker 0 3/8 et les Cotton Mülls à 2 sb.6.

div.head:
THE LAMBERT AFFAIR.
NO QUESTIONS FROM FRANCE

div.p: HorsE OF COMMONS.-In reply to an enquiry, Sir E. Grey informed Mr. Rutherford that France had made no representations concerning the Lambert affair.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE KOREAN TROUBLE.
JAPANESE TROOPS INSUFFICIENT.

div.p: There is inuch apprehension for the safety of the Japanese in the interior when the abdication becomes known. General Hasegawa has only 2800 troops, a number wholly in. adequate. The Korean regiment which furni shed the mutineers has refused to hand over their arms and ammunition and the Japanese are unable to compel them to do so, pending the arrival of reinforcements which are en route from Shimonoseki. Civilian agitators frequently harangue the Korean troops, who possess 90,000 rounds of ammunition. (R.)
The first edict of new Emperor orders punishment of the deputation to the Hague.
(Reuler)

div.head:
THE QUEEN OF HOLLAND.
THE TSAR'S HUMANITARIANISM.

div.p: Queen Wilhelmina gave a banquet to the first delegates of the powers. She praised the humanitarianism of the Tsar and wished the Conference a brilliant success. Mr. de Nelidoff thanked her.
(Havas)

div.head:
TURKS AND BULGARIANS.
FIGHT AT PERLEPE.

div.p: Turkish troops have exterminated a Bulgar. ian revolutionary band near Perlepe, killing 47 of them. The Turks had 16 casualties. Similar encounters on a smaller scale occur almost daily in Macedonia. (Reuter)

div.head:
SHEREEF OF WAZZAN.
FAILS TO INFLUENCE TRIBES.

div.p: The mission of the Shereef of Wazzan has entirely failed and he has returned to Alcazar. It appears that El Raisuli's influence with the tribes is greater than the Shereef's. (Reuter)
The S.S. "San Pedro" collided in a fog with the steamer "Columbia," bound for Portland : the "Columbia" sank about ; 100 persons have been drowned and 899 saved. (Reuter)

The great Norddeutscher liner "Kaiser Wil helm II," whilst loading coal at Bremerhaven snddenly listed to port. The water rushed into the bunkers and boilers and filled the whole ship, which is half submerged. Pumping is proceeding satisfactory but the vessel cannot be used for a considerable time. (Renter)
The Baltic dockmen have received orders to hasten the constrnction of several cruisers of 20,000 tons.
(Havas)

The "Figaro" says that Prince von Buelow stated in an interview that there is a break in Franco-German relations, which will in time, however, be transformed into an agreement.
(Havas)

The account of a long interview with Prince von Buelow has been published in the "Figaro." 11 The Chancellor said that an improvement of the relations between France and Germany had begun. The French could feel assured that Germany would place no obstacles in their path with regard to Morocco. He believed that the two countries might also come to an agreement on economic matters. (Reuter)
The piercing of the Tauern tunnel is com. pleted.
(Havas)
Mr. Clemenceau and General Picquart have been manœuvring in the balloon "Patrie."(H.)

div.head: SUDAN RAINS
div.p: Rains fell at Kawa and Geteina on Friday afternoon. A storm that raged Friday afternoon and night interrupted telegraphic communications.

The Irrigation Service has employed 120 Ghaffirs and stationed them along the newly constructed irrigation works in the Kassala province, in order to keep watch over the canals and embankments. The Gash flood is expected to reach Kassala shortly.
Owing to storms, telegraphic communications are still interrupted between Khartoum and Kordofan, and Khartoum and the eastern Sudan.

div.head: A NEW VERDI OPERA.
div.p: It is announced from Milan that the score of a Verdi opera, the existence of which was not Previously suspected, has been discovered in the Villa Verdi at Santa Agata. The tamons composer, in his will, requested that al cabinet full of papers should be destroyed, but the request was not complied with, and it was in this cabinet that the score was found. It appears to be an early work. Musical circles are greatly interested by the report of the discovery.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: TENDERS.

Tenders for the supply of Petroleum to British Troops at Khartoum for a period of 12 months from 14th September 1907 will be received at the office of Officer Commanding Army Service Corps, British Barracks, Khartoum, until 12 noon Thursday 15th August 1907.

Forms of Tender and all information may be obtained from the Officer Commanding Army Service Corps, British Head Quarters Cairo or the Officer Commanding Army Service Corps, British Barracks, Khartoum.
The Governor-General Sudan does not bind himself to accept the lowest or any Tender.
Tenders should be addressed to the Officer Commanding, Army Service Corps, British Barracks, Khartoum, and marked on the out side "Tender for Petroleum." 30684-2-1

div.head: *EASTERN SINAJ:
div.p: physciations withor described it in climbing on
sleepinbots babab, pre-lights
TÓPOGRAPHY AND GEOLOGY. av

-- Another volume has just been published of the interesting series, which the Survey Department is issuing, dealing with the geology and topography of out-of the way parts of Egypt. The latest work deals with the Eastern portion of the Sinaitic peninsula. From its association Sinai will always occupy & peculiar niche in the history of the world and its physical features are as grand as its historical associations with the sublime Mosaic story. As a recent writer described it

"With regard to the mountain climbing, the experience of Mr. Home and his expedition is the same as that of Sir Charles Wilson and the other members of the Ordnanoe Sorvey of Sinai, viz :-that no peak in Sinai is absolutely inacoessible. Mr. Hume's plan was to attack any mountain that was necessary as a station, however formidable it might appear, the attempt being in all cases crowned with success. One other point may be mentioned, viz:--the supposed dangers connected with an expedition in Eastern Sinai. There is no doubt that the Sinai Arab entertains & great dread of the dwellers on the eastern shores of the Gulf of Akaba, the inhabitants of 1. Magna especially having a bad reputation. On only one occasion did Mr. Hume's party feel any necessity for sleeping under arms, this being due to several bosts having put out from Magna to reconnoltre at Dabab, probably in consequence of their having seen our-lights when we were taking some observations on a hill above the camp. Interference by the Turks seemed also to be much feared, but though the expedition worked far north of a line which the chief sheikh, Modakhel, had asked us not to cross, there was no suggestion at any time of danger from this quarter."

"The Peninsula of Sinai, or at any rate the greater part of it, is in reality one of the most mountainous and intricate regions on the face of the earth : sand is & feature seldom met with, plains are rather the exception than the rule, the roads are often steep and rugged, and for the most part through a labyrinth of narrow rock-bound valleys. It is a desert, certainly, in the fullest sense of the word, but a desert of rock, gravel, and boulder, of gaunt peaks, dreary ridges, and arid valleys and plateaux, the whole forming a scene of stern desolation which tally merits its description as the "great and terrible wilderness.' So far from there being nothing to survey, the topo grapher may well shrink from the task of delineating its countless intricacies.'" Yet here and there, where after sudden thunderstorms the storm-waters rush down the main valleys, are found some fertile spots, oases of palms, seyal trees and rushes, producing pic: tures full of life and beauty in the midst of the stern hills that surround them. Perennial streams run down the wadis*: of Kyd, Hebran and Isla, in the latter valley forming a small waterfall whose sides are covered with maidenhair fern ; groves of tamarisk and palm fill the upper portions of Nasb gorge; while at Dahab and Nebk the latter fringe the coast-line at the points where the two great drainages of Nasb and Kyd enter the Gulf of Akaba. Nevertheless these occurrences are rare, and in many places, as near Ras Mohammed and in the schistose bills south of Dahab, unmitigated desolation holds sway.

The portion of Eastern Sinai considered in this memoir extends from Ain el-Hudera in latitude 29° N. to the southern end of the peninsula at Ras Mohamed, the part most particularly studied and mapped in detail being the triangular area bounded on the north by the transverse range, and to the east and south by the Gulf of Akaba and the Red Sea. This isolated position behind rugged mountain. barriers traversed only by passes, themselves not especially easy, is of itself & reason why this region has been so largely neglected, while in addition, it is at a cousiderable distance from Suez and Tor, the only ports of the peninsula. Thus it requires & six days' journey from Suez to the Shelala Pass, which is the gate of the south-eastern triangle, the same point being reached from Tor in four days, and then only after passing over the steep and boulder-strewn col at the head of the Tarfa valley.

The early history of Pastern Sinai is wrapped in obscurity, though many writers believe that the Israelites on leaving Sinai marched to the two famong wells of Wadi-el-Ain and Ain elHudera, their second station, that of Hazeroth, being somewhere in their neighbourhood. Be that as it may, the presence of numerous stone circles of very faried form and often placed in most unexpeeted localities, shows that man was at one time far more widely distributed in the region than he is at present, over thirty perfectly circular stone ciroles being sometimes placed close together on a single gravel terrace. | That these must be of very ancient date is proved by the occurrence of Nabathean (Idumean) inscriptions on some of these building at the foot of Abu Mesud, but there is at present no evidence in support of the Buggestion made by Mr. Holland, thint thoy may have owed their origin to the Amalekite With these exceptions, the reeords are silent, no Borption inseriptions having been met

n Sinki and I trmoon of a Roman occupation being abront, althongh the peninsnla was annexed to the Roman empire

by Cornelius Palma, prefect of Syria. The Nabatheans were a people from the north-east, who took possession of the commercial route abandoned by the Phoenicians, and from the famous rocky city of Petra commanded the peninsula down to about the period of the birth of Christ.

Only with the growth of the monastie principle among the early Christians in the fourth century did this wilderness again become peopled with hermits, who could in these moun. tain fastnesses find thesolitude they sought, and who have left the traces of their presence in the rectangular stone buildings generally low doored and roofless which are situated in the most out-of-the-way localities.

These isolated outposts were particularly subject to the inroads of the wild tribes of these mountainous regions, the Saracens and Blemmyes having on several occasions carried out massacres on a large scale, while after the rise of the Moslem power, the mountaineers seem to have made an easy transition to the new religion, and to-day the Sinai Convent alone remains as an interesting relio of the prevalence of monasticism in the peninsula, Although the eastern mountain region thus early ceases to play any part in the historical record, the Galf of Akaba has at many periods been the snocessful rival of the Gulf of Snez, being the principal waterway not only for the fleets of Solomon and Ahab, but also of great importance to the Crusaders and Saracens ; Akaba, at the head of the eastern gulf, being the scene of many fierce fights, before Saladin finally obtained the mastery. As Dean Stanley has given an eloquent account of these changes, in his work on "Sinai and Palestine" the reader is referred to the latter for further information. The peninsnla is administer, ed by the Intelligence Department of the Egyptian War Office, the chief governient official in the peninsula being the Commandant of Sinai, who resides at Kala'at el-Nakhi, there being also a Nazir 1 at. Tor, though the latter town is practically controlled by the Quarantine Board having its centre at Alexandria. The relations between the Government and the tribesmen are negociated through the head sheikhs of the peninsula, each separate tribe having also its own sheikh, who seems to be invested with considerable authority.

The inhabitants of this mountainous region have fully maintained their good reputation for honesty, readiness to oblige, and independence of character. In general they are slight in build and somewhat short in stature, but very active climbers and keen sportsmen. Even the children early learn to recognize the plants and animals with which they come in contact, and the necessity of finding water and camel-food brings them into close acquaintance with every recess of their hills. Their | dwellings are of the simplest description, consisting of dark or striped cloth stretched on a few poles, and so placed as to be under the protection of some rocky ridge. A partition in the centre divides them into quarters, the mens' from the womens', while furniture is limited to camel-saddles, baskets for obtaining camel-fodder, water-jars and a few other
primitive ntensils. 1 This new publication is excellent:y printed and is illustrated with a number of beautiful views. Herr Guyot, of Helwan, kindly I permitted the Survey Department to use his
photographic material for the purposes of this memoir, the views having been obtained by him during two scientific expeditions to Sinai.
A military officer with civil power

div.head: LES
div.p: "EGYPTIAN TEMPLES." |
AN IMPORTANT EXHIBITION.
By W. Sr. CHAD BOSCAWEN.

"Something attempted, something done, are the words that should be inseribed over the entrance of the exhibition now being held by the Egypt Exploration Hand at Kings College. This exhibition marks the completion of a most important work, the exploration of the two grant temple of Hathor, under the | cliffs of Deir El-Bahari-near Thebea. i For over fourteen years (1892-1907) the Fund has been engaged in not only clearing the temples but restoring the fallen soulptures where possible and this has entailed an average expenditure of about £1,000 each season
Shortly before the completion of the great +Hathor Temple, built by Queen Hatsbeper

in the eighteenth Dynasty, & most im portant discovery was made by Profes Bor & Naville and Mr. H. R. Hall of the Bgyptian Department of the Bri tish Museum, who was working with him, of still older temple, built by King Mentubetep II., called by the curious prenomen of Nebhateo-Ra, "Lord of the Steering Paddle of Ra," & king of the eleventh Dynasty, abont B.C. 2500. It is from this temple that the antiquities now exhibited at King's College come. The edifice was clearly the tomb-temple of the King, and the curious stunted pyramid in the centre of the block was the sign of the tomb. The four years' work upon the site has now completed the exploration of one of the most remarkable buildings in Egypt. A great royal tomb was discovered, the entrance passage to which was hewn five hundred feet in the moun-1. tain, and at the end was a splendid chamber lined with granite and alabaster. No coffin was found, but a huge alabaster 'naos" of honey alabaster, twelve feet high and ten feet wide, with red granite beams to support the roof, was found. The tomb had been plundered, and the burial disturbed, but mach of the furniture was found, and is here, exhibited on Table E. Alabaster canoptio vases with wooden lids, statues of officials and servants, little wooden figures beautifully carved, bows of curious wood, probably from Punt, arrows, staffs of offence, from which the gold plating had been stripped, and portions of a human skall and bones (but these Professor Naville regards as remains of a later burial) were also found. Near here are some fine funeral boats, one with complete crew, figures, of soldiers, servants, bakers, and brewers from the tombs of the princesses.

The most interesting exhibits here are the coloured bas reliefs from the walls of the colonnade round the pyramid. This work is entirely new, and shows that the art of the Eleventh Dynasty was a renasance of the old art then considerably improved. Its principal featare, is high relief with minute attention to detail-as note the portrait of the King and Queen (Table B. 4), or the figure
of a priesters (C7), and the fine figures of I priestesses (C 11). Especially fine in finish is

the unfortunately broken group of the King holding the hand of the Queen (C 12). The modelling of the limbs is most accurate, and this is very important, for we have here, in | all probability, the work of the celebrated painter-sculptor Mertisen, and his son who says on his townb-stone, I know the right drawing of a hard or & foot, the action of one walking." For a striking example of the work of this school is a slab representing the King standing with Hathor behind him. The modelling of the figures, and the brillance of colour, and the finish of the bieroglyphs, each of them a miniature portrait, mark them as the work of true artists. Of war there is little illustration, only some scenes representing a war against the Amo, or "people of Sinai," and here the ethnic features are well preserved. It must be remembered that this year's work was a clear
ing-up of the rubbish heaps ; 80 many of the | exhibits are small, but the beauty of the work

is preserved. Sinall exhibits are well worth attention. Blocks from the pavement on which pilgrims (B.C. 2400 have outlined their sandals and then scratched their names, i.e., Meri and Huy, on the sole. Such mementoes are often

found on the lead roofs of our churches. The | blue glazed wire is very fine. There are figures of the sacred cow of Hathor in painted limestone. This blne glazed ware was frequently dedicated to Hathor, as the goddess of the turquoise. The collection of workmen's toots, &c., mallets, hoes, malls, mats, and brushes for the sculptors to clear away dust are exhibited, as well as some fine basket work. About the time of the twentieth dynasty this temple appears to have been given over to the quarrymen, who broke the sculptures and even drilled holes in the octagon columns of the colonnade to cut them down, hence, the destruction. It is these workmen (1) to whom the tools belong. The whole exhibition is full of interest and should well ropay a visit. There will be lectures on "Exploration of the Temple, "by Mr. Conelly, also on the Batodus," and by Mr. H. R. Hall on "Thebes." The exhibition remains open a month. ("The Globe.") monu

div.head: AVERTISSEMENT
div.p: Le 13 Juillet Mr. Georges Pantélidis agé de 12 ans a été mordu au Casino San Stefano pas un chien de petite taille, race européenne sous-poil fauve clair. L'animal a été conduit au Fort Kamarieh par les soins du Caracol de Flemming et mis aussitot sous observation.

Dès le lendemain apparaissaient une série de symptômes qui rendaient l'animal fortement suspect. Le père de l'intéressé a été avisé que par mesure de précaution l'enfant devrait être aussitôt dirigé sur un établissement antirabique.
Aujourd'hui le donte n'est plus possible, l'animal se trouve dans la phase qui suit souvent l'accès de rage Furieuse (Rage Paralytique).

La Municipalité en portant ces faits à la connaissance du public a eu en vue non senlement de le mettre en gardecontre l'approche de chiens inconnus qui très souvent ne présentent aucun signe apparent de rage, mais aussi de l'engager à une stricte observation des prescriptions du règlement sur les chiens qui exigent leur musellement ou leur tente en laisse ; les plus graves dangers penvent naitre en effet d'une imprudence on d'me inobservation de ces prescriptions. Alexandrie le 19 Juillet 1907.
L'Administrateur 30668-3-2
W. P. CHATAWAY.
yptian State Railways.

UL NOTICE. The Railway Administration has the honour to inform the Public that on and from the 1st August 1907, through-bookings with the Egyptian State Railways, via Roda Junction, will be in operation for goods of every description, by Grande and Petite Vitesse, including carriages and animals, at the undermentioned stations of the Upper Egypt Agricultural Railways. Further details may be obtained from the Goods Manager's Office Cairo, or from the office of the General Superintendent Agricultural Railways, Minieh.
Idara Ezbet Merheb Naway Sheikh Imbarek Sharawy Rideh Karam Beni-Ahmed Gahasha Ezbet Abaza Saleh Pasha Talleh 30671-2-2
harm
NOTICE.
The Egyptian State Railways hereby give notice to the Public that the competitive. examination of candidates for the Traffic service has been postponed from July 20th to August,5th.

Candidates who have passed the examination for the Primary Education Certificate but have not yet obtained their certificate from the Ministry of Education, can produce for the present their bench numbers, and if they pass the Railway Administration's examination they will then be asked to produce their Pri. fnary Certificate.
Candidates who are desirous of attending the above examination are requested to send their names to the Traffic Manager before August 1st. Cairo, July 19th 1907.
Administration des Chemins de fer
de l'Etat Bgyptien
AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a l'honneur d'informer le Public, qu'à partir du 1er Août 1907, "les marchandises de tout espèce, y compris les voitures et les ! animaux, seront acceptées au transport en commun, par Grande on Petite vitesse, avec les Chemins de Fer de l'Etat, via Jonction de Roda, aux gares ci-dessous mentionnées.
Pour plus amples renseignements, le Public est prié de s'adresser au Bureau du Service des Marchandises au Caire ou à celui deMr. le Directeur des Chemins de Fer Agricoles a Minieh.
Idara Ezbet Merheb Naway
Sheikh Imbarek Sharawy Rideh Karam Beni-Ahmed Cahasha Ezbet-Abasa Saleh Pasha Talleh
